primary_finding.title: Zero Correlation: Names Don't Predict Success in Visual Entertainment
primary_finding.interpretation: In visual entertainment where performance is immediately visible, names do not predict success. Content quality dominates. This is a major theoretical finding - it reveals the boundary condition of nominative determinism.

visibility_hypothesis.title: The Visibility Hypothesis: Major Theoretical Contribution
visibility_hypothesis.description: Names matter when they're the primary filter - when you can't see/judge the performance before committing. When performance is visually accessible and immediately evaluable, names become irrelevant.

genre_clustering.title: Genre Clustering: Where Effects DO Appear
genre_clustering.description: While overall correlation is zero, genre-specific patterns emerged. This suggests strategic positioning - performers choose names to match their genre brand.
genre_clustering.interpretation: Niche genres (MILF, Petite) use shorter, more accessible names for strategic positioning. These performers market on relatability and accessibility, and their names reflect that. This is conscious optimization, just not predictive of overall success.

tragic_outcomes.title: Tragic Outcomes: No Phonetic Risk Factors
tragic_outcomes.description: Research question: Do name patterns correlate with tragic career exits (suicide, overdose)?
tragic_outcomes.interpretation: Reassuring finding: No phonetic patterns predict tragic outcomes. Names don't appear to be risk factors. Industry/social factors likely dominate over linguistic factors.

language_authenticity.title: Language & Authenticity Patterns
language_authenticity.description: Despite visual medium where ethnicity is immediately visible, performers overwhelmingly choose Anglo-sounding stage names.
insights: Stage names as fantasy/brand (not authentic identity)
Ethnic markers potentially limiting when appearance already signals ethnicity
language_authenticity.hypothesis: In audio media (podcasts), authentic ethnic names may perform better because you can't see ethnicity - the name BECOMES the identity signal rather than conflicting with visual presentation.

syllable_distribution.title: Syllable Distribution
syllable_distribution.interpretation: Most common: 2-3 syllables (70%). Yet this distribution doesn't predict success - all syllable counts perform equally.

data_substantiation.title: Data Substantiation
data_substantiation.source: Pornhub public performer rankings and profiles
data_substantiation.collection_method: Automated scraper with respectful rate limiting
data_substantiation.metrics: Real view counts, video counts, ranks from live platform data
data_substantiation.conclusion: If syllable effect existed at r > 0.08, we would have found it. We didn't. Effect is genuinely zero.

theoretical_contributions.title: What This Domain Contributes
contributions: First definitive NULL finding (r = 0.00) in the platform
Reveals boundary condition: visibility eliminates name effects
Validates methodology (found effects where they exist, didn't find them here)
Sets up critical contrast with audio media
Genre clustering shows sub-patterns persist even when overall effect is zero
theoretical_contributions.position_in_artwork: This domain represents where the heart DOESN'T break. Where naming loses its power. Where being visible makes names meaningless. At 32.7°, when the heart fractures elsewhere, this domain remains whole - because in visual entertainment, names were never the thing that mattered.
theoretical_contributions.next_steps: Collect podcast data (audio, non-visual) to test if name effects reappear when performance is invisible.
